Comments_Questions: How clearly did the instructor define the topic of study
How clearly did the instructor outline the expectation for the course, classroom activity and homework
How well were individual class sessions prepared and presented
How well did lectures fit within the boundaries of the course
How available was the instructor for help outside the classroom
How useful were assignments in furthering an understanding of the topic
If tests were given, how fairly did they measure knowledge gained?
How useful was this course in preparing you for production work
How would you evaluate the instructor's knowledge of the material
Please offer additional comments on such topics as: what worked best about the course, suggested improvements, class materials, etc.
Comments_List: Good layout of what was to be covered.
Having his book for class helped define exactly what was going to be covered.

The topic was clear in a broad sense, but I'm unclear on the purpose of the course. For an introductory course, there were too many specifics, but nothing was specific enough for a specialized course. 

Some work on the syllabus, and a deeper questioning about the purpose of this course should happen in the near future.
We all knew what was due and when.  How assignments were to be delivered was unclear, as in: printed or e-mailed, powerpoint or something else.
The assignments were oftentimes vague and open to interpretation

I was unclear on the specific requirements for all assignments. I did them to the best of my ability, but I was never sure if I was doing what was expected. The first two assignments need more specificity - they use language that may be familiar to the professor, but not nessecarily to the students. 

The last assignment, at the end of the day, is a drafting assignment. I would hope for something more.

The instructor did not seem to do any due diligence in preparing for class outside of creating the powerpoint presentation.  Such as having the right connectors for the projector, having enough seats in the room. The instructor also was lacking in notifying students when perpetually late to class.  Classes either started late, or ran over time, thus making it harder on students to plan and navigate their days.
I know he's busy, but it seems like sometimes he put together the lecture that day

Some class sessions were more dynamic than others, and it's hard to say why exactly. Most likely, it was due to the nature of the material covered: generalized topics were less interesting than overviews of very specific code requirements.

We often wound up running out of time because Gene didn't have a good handle on how long a given subject would take. 

I appreciate that he loves what he does, but I could have done with a few less tangents. Especially tangents that are really only interesting to him.

Class sessions were presented in a casual manner, but always with a clearly defined topic or theme to be covered.  Sometimes classes would rush a bit towards the end to fit in as much material as possible.

The course lectures covered themes outlined in the syllabus, but were sometimes rushed towards the end to cover all material.  Class sessions were often carried out in a casual, but topic-focused manner, which helped maintain the trajectory of the course.
When the instructor was well prepared and on time, the lectures were well delivered and concise.  Always better when it is a discussion in addition to a lecture, and not just a straight lecture.

One of the best days of the course was the tour around New Haven. That said, I'm not sure what it has to do with the rest of the course.

Is this a course in architecture? In building codes? In theatre history? Please decide.

Assignments were adequate and interesting.  The final critique should have taken two class periods, or a longer class.  The guest judges were a pleasure to hear from, and we could have used their input during the check in, and not just at the end.
The workload was very well balanced. I was able to do all the class readings and and all projects on time

As with the nature of a design practicum, much of the work was weighted towards the end of the course in the last assignment. Perhaps one or two more weeks dedicated to the production of the final assignment would have allowed more balance in the workload of the course.

Much of the emphasis of the course was weighted on the last two assignments, and I wish less emphasis/time had been placed on the first two in order to allow us more time to explore code analysis and start our theater design at an earlier point in the semester.
Instructor was either on campus for class, or otherwise unavailable.
Gene was always available via email, and was eager to share additional materials with interested parties.
Always responsive via email....
always responsive via email.
The code analysis project was fascinating and useful.

The assignments were probably the essential part of the class. They were crucial in furthering the understanding of the material covered in class. All the assignments (except, probably, the Profile) were also very fun to do.
The last assignment was useful, the rest not-so-much.

I would have appreciated more building code analysis assignments, rather than a tour of New Haven architecture and an architectural critique, though I understand the need for those with little/no prior architectural knowledge to develop a more robust vocabulary in order to describe their own work.  Nevertheless I think the goals of the course were more tailored towards a focus on the 3rd and 4th assignments and wish we had spent a bit more time with the 3rd assignment or similar code analysis work.

I wish more focus was given to the 3rd assignment in building code analysis, and the collaborative presentation that followed.  I think more assignments of this nature would have helped us cover more material in the course.
There were no tests
Unless you are preparing to be a Theatre Consultant, these classes are not for you.
Currently the coursework in the theatre planning track have no ways of preparing for production work at YSD
This course provided unique and extremely valuable information in the condensed way.
There are no theatre-planning production assignments to prepare for.

Greatly appreciated the chance to present my final work to a panel of experts, and gained a lot from the questions and perspectives raised during this presentation.  I wish we had potentially had similar exposure to these experts throughout the design process, perhaps in one or two more consulting sessions.
I particularly appreciated the panel of experts that were invited to our final design presentations and the conversations/diverse perspectives that were shared regarding the work.
Seemed to have an acute knowledge of certain topics, but lacked details in others.
incorporate more discussions and less rote lectures.
Having more interactions with architects or other theater planners would be great. Scaling back the final project (designing a theatre) i think would be a good idea.

The classes I enjoyed the most, were the ones with discussions and feedback from Gene, guest professionals, or fellow students. It would be great to incorporate more activities of this type into class sessions.

The code analysis assignment was particularly effective in the course and wish more focus had been placed on similar types of collaborative analysis assignments.  The chance to tour Yale's theater spaces with experts and analyze particular design decisions within the spaces was incredible illuminating and fulfilling.
